august 2016.headline: Pepper spray: after the investigation
august 2016.description: University of Maryland Police incorrectly deployed pepper spray at a graduation party of predominantly black students, prompting outrage on social media and the two-week suspension of an officer. A five-week internal investigation did not discover evidence the incident was racially motivated, but some students disagreed. This incident occurred one week after Philando Castile and Alton Sterling, two black men, died at the hands of police officers. Read about UMPD’s investigation and watch body camera footage in The Diamondback’s coverage.

september 2016.headline: University of Maryland will decrease parking spaces and increase fees by fall 2018
september 2016.description: DOTS Director David Allen announced plans to eliminate nearly 3,000 parking spaces by fall 2018 due to ongoing construction projects. He said DOTS will also restrict freshmen and sophomores from parking on campus starting fall 2017, with some exceptions. Students who wish to park on campus will also face a nearly 20 percent fee increase.

september 2016.headline: The SGA wants to add a mandatory student fee to fund UMD's Title IX office
september 2016.description: DOTS Director David Allen announced plans to eliminate nearly 3,000 parking spaces by fall 2018 due to ongoing construction projects. He said DOTS will also restrict freshmen and sophomores from parking on campus starting fall 2017, with some exceptions. Students who wish to park on campus will also face a nearly 20 percent fee increase.

september 2016.headline: The SGA wants to add a mandatory student fee to fund UMD's Title IX office
september 2016.description: Under the leadership of current Student Government Association President A.J. Pruitt, who was the student affairs vice president at the time, the SGA proposed a plan to charge every student a mandatory fee that would help support this university’s underfunded Office of Civil Rights and Sexual Misconduct. The SGA ultimately withdrew the proposal in October but pledged to continue to advocate and raise funds for the office.
